skill.name: perigon-agent
skill.description: Pointers for Copilot/agents to apply Perigon conventions
skill.summary: Provides project conventions, directory structure, and coding standards for AI agents working on Perigon projects
skill.author: AterDev

security_audit.summary: Static scanner detected URL patterns and file references. Evaluation confirms these are benign: source_url is GitHub metadata, documentation links are standard references, and 'weak cryptographic algorithm' findings are scanner false positives (line numbers exceed file bounds). This is a development conventions guide with no malicious intent.

content.value_statement: AI code generators lack project-specific context. This skill provides Perigon conventions so agents follow correct directory structure, naming patterns, and coding standards when generating code.
actual_capabilities: Guides AI agents to use correct backend directory locations for entities, managers, DTOs, controllers, and host configuration
Maps frontend Angular project structure including routes, services, components, and i18n files
Provides key documentation references for development conventions, business logic patterns, and API design
Establishes coding defaults including RESTful APIs, Code First EF, Guid v7 IDs, and error handling patterns
Instructs agents to ask clarifying questions when entity or module details are unclear
Sets global rules: prioritize accuracy, avoid builds unless requested, check diagnostics first
limitations: This skill only provides guidance for Perigon projects; conventions do not apply to other codebases
Does not generate code directly; it instructs AI agents on how to generate compliant code
Documentation links point to external resources that may become outdated
Does not enforce conventions at build time; compliance depends on agent adherence

use_cases.title: New Developer Onboarding
use_cases.description: When a developer or AI agent needs to understand the Perigon project layout before writing or modifying code, this skill ensures correct file placement and naming.
use_cases.target_user: New developers and AI coding assistants

use_cases.title: Code Generation Projects
use_cases.description: When using Claude, Codex, or Claude Code to generate features for a Perigon backend or frontend, this skill ensures the output follows project conventions.
use_cases.target_user: Software engineers using AI code generators

use_cases.title: Architecture Consistency Reviews
use_cases.description: When reviewing AI-generated code for Perigon projects, this skill serves as a reference to verify adherence to ManagerBase pattern, error handling, and RESTful standards.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Perigon Coding Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new RESTful API endpoint for {entity_name} in the Perigon project. Place the controller in the correct Services folder, use the ManagerBase pattern, and follow the project's error handling conventions.
prompt_templates.scenario: When you need a simple API endpoint following Perigon conventions

prompt_templates.title: Backend Module Development
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a complete module for {module_name} including the entity definition, EF configuration, DTOs, manager class, and controller. Follow Perigon's Code First EF pattern, use Guid v7 for IDs, and apply select projections instead of heavy Include statements.
prompt_templates.scenario: When developing a new backend feature module

prompt_templates.title: Frontend Feature Implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new Angular feature with route configuration in app.routes.ts, associated service, and any shared components needed. Follow Perigon's frontend conventions and integrate with existing i18n assets.
prompt_templates.scenario: When implementing a new frontend feature

prompt_templates.title: Convention Verification
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the following code for Perigon convention compliance: check directory structure, naming conventions, ManagerBase usage, error handling patterns, and RESTful API design. List any violations found.
prompt_templates.scenario: When verifying AI-generated code meets Perigon standards

output_examples.input: Generate a new API endpoint for managing user preferences
output_examples.output:
I'll create the UserPreferences endpoint following Perigon conventions:

1. Entity: src/Definition/Share/UserPreference.cs
2. EF Config: src/Definition/Entity/UserPreferenceConfiguration.cs
3. DTOs: src/Modules/UserPreferences/Models/
4. Manager: src/Modules/UserPreferences/Managers/UserPreferenceManager.cs
5. Controller: src/Services/UserApi/Controllers/UserPreferencesController.cs

The controller will use the ManagerBase pattern, return RESTful responses, and handle errors with BusinessException/Problem details.

output_examples.input: Where should I put a new authentication service in the Angular app?
output_examples.output: For the Angular frontend, place authentication-related services in src/ClientApp/WebApp/app/services/. Configure routes that require authentication in the guards and update app/app.routes.ts accordingly. Store any i18n authentication messages in assets/i18n/.

best_practices: Always check .github/copilot-instructions.md for global rules before generating code in Perigon projects
Ask for entity and module details when unclear rather than making assumptions about structure
Prefer select projections over Include statements to optimize query performance
anti_patterns: Do not assume project structure without consulting this skill's conventions
Avoid running builds or migrations automatically; wait for explicit requests
Do not create ApiResponse wrapper classes; return raw RESTful responses instead

faq.question: What is the Perigon project structure?
faq.answer: Perigon follows a modular architecture with definitions in src/Definition, managers and DTOs in src/Modules/{Mod}/, controllers in src/Services/*/Controllers, and the host application in src/AppHost. The frontend is an Angular application in src/ClientApp/WebApp.

faq.question: How do I find the global copilot instructions?
faq.answer: The global rules for AI agents are located in .github/copilot-instructions.md at the repository root. These rules emphasize accuracy first, avoiding builds unless asked, and checking diagnostics.

faq.question: What naming conventions does Perigon use?
faq.answer: Perigon uses Guid v7 for ID generation, follows C# naming standards for classes and methods, and applies the ManagerBase pattern for business logic. Controllers should follow RESTful naming conventions.

faq.question: Where do I put documentation links?
faq.answer: Key documentation for Perigon conventions is available at https://dusi.dev/docs/Perigon/en-US/10.0/ covering development conventions, business logic patterns, API design, and database access patterns.

faq.question: How should errors be handled in Perigon?
faq.answer: Use BusinessException for domain errors andProblemDetails for HTTP error responses. Avoid manager cross-calls and do not wrap responses in generic ApiResponse containers.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with non-Perigon projects?
faq.answer: No. This skill specifically provides conventions for Perigon projects only. Using these conventions on other codebases will result in incorrect file placements and naming patterns.
